SPEAKER 1: I want to thank
you all for joining us for our CRISPR 10 Years of
Genome Editing and More webinar

today. Today I have Dr.
Michael Snyder with me. Michael Snyder is the Stanford
Asherman Professor and Chair

of Genetics and the Director
of the Center of Genomics and Personalized Medicine.

Dr. Snyder received
his PhD training at the California
Institute of Technology

and carried out
post-doctoral training at Stanford University. He's a leader in the field
of functional genomics

and proteomics and one
of the major participants of the ENCODE project.

His laboratory study was the
first to perform a large scale functional genomics
project in any organism,

and has launched many
technologies in genomics and proteomics
that have been used for characterizing
genomes, proteomes,

and regulatory networks. Dr. Snyder, thank you
for being with us today.

MICHAEL SNYDER: Great. Fantastic. OK. Well, it's wonderful
to be here and tell you

some of the things that's
going on with CRISPR. So as was mentioned,
we're somewhat celebrating

10 years of genome editing. CRISPR as a phenomenon
was actually discovered in the '80s,
mostly as a genetic locus.

They didn't know what it
did, and it took a long time to figure out what it did. But really, about
10 years ago is

when it exploded as an
incredible technology for being able to edit our DNA.

And it's really had
profound consequences on many areas of biology, and
we'll talk about some of that.

So specifically what we're
going to go over-- well, I should mention I have a
lot of conflicts because I

found a lot of companies. And also, I'll
mention that if you do want to learn more, as
was mentioned earlier,

do take our CRISPR course and
even our genetics certificate program, Genetics and Genomics.

So here's what we're
going to cover today. We're going to talk a little
bit about what is CRISPR. We'll spend a fair amount
of time on its current uses

in medicine and
agriculture, et cetera. We'll talk about some of
the ethics and things you

might consider where this field
could go and its possibilities. We'll just touch briefly on
how this technology can be used

and incredible
research advances, and also a bit in
future directions.

All right. So what is CRISPR? Well, CRISPR stands for this
long name, Clustered Regularly

Interspaced Short
Palindromic Repeats. And I'll show you this a
little more on the next slide.

Basically, it's some
repetitive sequence. It was discovered as
this genetic locus. As I say, nobody
knew what it did.

In the end, it turns out it's
an antiviral defense system that bacteria use to actually
block, wipe out viruses that

try to invade them, and I'll
show you that in a minute as well. And relevant to
today's talk, it's

really emerged as an
incredible tool for editing DNA and much, much more,
as indicated here.

So basically, here's
how it was discovered. People were sequencing and
looking at loci of bacteria.

And what they
discovered was there's this CRISPR locus which
has these repeats.

That's actually this
bluish purple thing here. And then there were
these spacers in between

that were unique sequences. Flanking this--
and these turn out to get expressed as RNA, meaning
your DNA, for many of you know,

makes RNA of these
things, which later will get processed into
these sort of repeats

with these spacer
elements next to them. But also in this locus are a
set of genes that are actually

quite important as
well that are actually important for the cleavage, as
we'll talk about in a minute.

So this thing itself,
believe it or not, came from a bacterial virus. They call them bacteriophages.

But it was adapted from that. And then in the end, it's used,
actually, as a viral defense

mechanism for bacteria. So what happens is when other
viruses come into the cells,

they have homology to
these spacer elements here. This CRISPR system--
it's actually

a key set of proteins here--
plus this RNA, if you will, actually attacks
it and destroys it.

So it's an antiviral
strategy that bacteria use to protect themselves. And of course, then
it's gotten adapted

to be able to actually
re-engineer genomes because this idea that you
could cleave DNA turns out

to be very, very powerful. And the reason it
works so well is it's just incredibly efficient. And so in the latest rendition,
this is how things got adapted.

And I should point out this
is what led to a Nobel Prize two years ago for Jennifer
Doudna and Emmanuelle

Charpentier. So they basically
set up this system.

And really what it
involves doing is it's a single protein
system, and the protein

is kind of famous now. It's called Cas9. It's part of this CRISPR locus. And together with what
was the repeated element--

now it's sort of
engineered in its new way-- and a very specific
sequence called a guide.

So this was originally set
up to destroy, as I say, bacterial viruses. But you can actually set it
up with a sequence that's

actually homologous
to any region of DNA you want to modify.

And so what's done is these
are called guide RNAs. You have a part of
the sequence that's

homologous to the region
you want to modify, and together with some of the
key recognition sequencing

that's recognized by Cas9. And together, this
guide RNA plus Cas9 will make a
double-stranded break here.

So it's just two
components you need. Again, the protein
is this Cas9 and this

what's called guide RNA. And so the way this works
is that you would actually

get this in the cells. We'll go through this
more in a minute. And if you can get the protein
plus this guide RNA, what it'll

do is it'll find its
locus, the region where it's complementary
to, and it cleaves it.

And if you don't have any other
sequences, what will happen is it'll cleave that
locus, and then your cells

try and repair that. And they don't do it perfectly. They tend to actually
cleave out base.

It gets chewed up a little bit. And so you'll make one
to three base deletions, sometimes larger.

And basically that winds up
creating a mutation that gets sealed back up. And usually you get
deletions of some key bases.

So this actually, then, can
modify any locus you want. Now this has some use,
but it's not as useful

as if you can make a very
specific modification. And so it's been adapted one
more time, where you actually

do the same thing,
but instead of just letting it repair itself, you
add what's called a template.

You add the sequence you would
like to see get replaced. And then, instead
of the other thing

was called non-homologous end
joining for the aficionados out there. But what'll happen here is
that you can use homology,

the complementary sequences. I know this is a little
sophisticated for some of you who don't have a
strong background here.

I guess that's why you
would take our program. But basically, what will
happen is if you give it

a sequence you want
to fix-- say you have an original
mutation in this locus-- you can put in the
normal sequence.

And with this CRISPR
system, you can repair it. So you basically go back in
and you'll take a piece of DNA

and fix it. And so that's extremely,
extremely powerful. And so that's what's been done.

It's been done in lots of cells,
and you'll see in a minute, in organisms and stuff
as well all right.

So here is how you do this. You actually would take a
region you want to modify.

And you would actually have
this homologous sequence together with the
guide sequence,

and then also the Cas9 protein. You would either
embed this thing--

you can encode it, this
thing, into a virus, and there are ways of doing
that, say, lentiviruses

or AAV or other
kinds of viruses, things actually, believe
it or not, we go through

in our certificate
program, and/or you can use, these days,
some of these they're called

nanoparticles, these
lipid embedded particles. These are things they use for
vaccines now, COVID and such.

And either way, you can
coat the key elements here and transfer them into cells.

And so they'll go
inside the cell, and then they'll edit the genome
in the way I just described.

And to make sure
it's right that you did make the right
correction, you actually would determine the
sequence of that region

and make sure everything
is what you thought it was. And so it works. And what's special about
the CRISPR-Cas system,

as they call it, is that it's
extremely, extremely efficient. And it often works not just--

we have two copies, as you
may know, of all of our DNA, one from our mom,
one from our dad. It often fixes it on both
copies, not just one.

So it's very, very powerful. So basically, then,
as you might imagine,

this has been used a lot. It's been used in a lot in
research, re-engineering cells, for studying biological systems.

And there's a ton
of activity there. I'll mentioned some of
this at the very, very end. But it's being used a
lot in medicine as well.

And I thought I
would review some of the applications
for that here, and then that'll
leave us lots of time

for questions, by
the way, at the end. And so basically it's
turned out to have very profound implications in
all kinds of areas of medicine.

And I'll run you
through a few examples. There's now a number of
trials out there using CRISPR.

Certainly the most
advanced trial is actually to fix
a disease that's reasonably common called
sickle cell disease.

It's really very prevalent in
certain parts of the world, and African-Americans as
well in the United States,

and in other groups as well. And also, there's another
related disease called thalassemia that's also
a red blood cell disease.

And these folks, they
basically have a mutation in a hemoglobin gene.

It's an important part
of your red blood cells. Your hemoglobin, as
you probably know, it carries oxygen. It's in your
red blood cells, carries oxygen

to all your tissues,
really, really important to oxygenate all your cells. And people who have the sickle
cell disease, they basically,

their cells, they don't work
as well is the bottom line. And the cells get misshapen.

As shown here, they'll
actually become stiff and block blood vessel, what have you.

And some forms are very mild,
some forms are pretty extreme.

And so it turns out there's
two ways that people have been trying to fix folks with this.

And one is basically in the
STEM cells, if you will,

there's two tricks. One, the latest
is actually trying to fix the mutation itself.

If you see the mutation, you
go in and try and fix it. And that's being done here
at Stanford by Matt Porteus.

Another trick that people
use, believe it or not, you actually have two
forms of hemoglobin.

You have one when
you're a fetus, and then you have another
one once you've been born.

It switches this one
form of hemoglobin to another, from what's
called fetal hemoglobin

to the adult form. And nobody knows why we
have those two, but we do.

And basically, you can actually,
instead of directly trying to fix the adult
form, you can just

make the fetal form active. And so you can basically
inhibit or remove

the gene that turns
this thing off. And so the bottom
line, the trick

here is that you just leave
either fetal hemoglobin on or you fix the mutation here.

And it turns out from
preliminary trials-- the numbers are still small. One trial had about 14 people.

Another had somewhere
only half a dozen. They're a little
further along now. But it turns out it works.

It works enough to get roughly
30% to 40% normal levels

of hemoglobin. And that's enough,
actually, to fix people. You don't need
100% to fix people.

So so far the data are
very, very encouraging, and so this is starting
to look pretty good.

So they call this thing ex
vivo because you're actually fixing a person's stem
cells outside of their body.

You collect their
stem cells, fix them, and then you return them back
with these modifications.

And it works pretty well. So this is now being considered
for many other things,

a very related condition
called beta thalassemia. It's also a red
blood cell disorder.

But then there's some other
very, very debilitating, I'm sure you know,
diseases as well,

Duchenne muscular
dystrophy and some of these other things,
again, that are listed here.

This one affects the eye. This one's a nerve
and heart disease. This amyloid is
affecting nerve cells.

And people are
trying these well. But people like to
actually try to fix the eye for a lot of reasons.

First of all, it turns
out it's fairly isolated from your immune system. It's an ideal area where people
try gene therapies a lot.

And also, a lot of people have
some severe problems with eyes. So to cure blindness
is a big deal.

So anyway, there are
people who are actually trying to do these
corrections, if you will,

for each of these
different diseases. And these trials are underway. There's quite a few
different trials.

There's a lot of
other things where people are very interested
in yet haven't quite

reached trials, or maybe
they're just starting. I think most of these
have not started yet, but people would like to.

There's early forms
of Alzheimer's that if you can fix, that
would obviously be huge.

People get Alzheimer's very
young age, say '30s and 40s. Cystic fibrosis, you may
know, is relatively prevalent.

Huntington's is an
absolutely incurable disease as it currently exists.

So to be able to fix
this would be huge. Tay-Sachs, also, as far
as I know, no known cures,

and fragile X. So being
able to go in and manipulate the genetic regions
responsible for these diseases

would, in fact, be
a huge, huge deal. And there are the
ways of treating for certain forms
of cystic fibrosis,

but not for most
forms, actually. Most of those others
are not curable.

So these single gene mutations
that I mentioned before, people are trying to fix.

It turns out CRISPR is
also being used for cancer. And this gets a
little complicated. Again, we cover it
somewhat in our course.

But CRISPR is being used a ton
in basic research for cancer. So manipulating
cells, manipulating

mice to be able to
study models of cancer. But it's actually being
used in patients now.

So some trials
have started here. And there are several
versions of this.

What you can do is it turns out
cancer cells are very clever. They've come up with a way of
sort of a don't eat me signal

that basically means that their
immune system is a special set of cells called T cells.

Cancer cells make a
protein on the surface that is recognized by these T
cells and says, hey, I'm self.

You shouldn't eat me. You shouldn't attack me. And so they've figured out how
to get around our immune system

by doing just that. So when you get cancer,
they figured out how to basically block
your immune cells

from attacking them. And so there are ways
of tricking, then,

to get back and try
and re-engineer T cells to be able to attack them.

And one way to do this is to
get rid of that signal here. If you don't have
the signal, cancer

will look like foreign
cells and your T cell will actually destroy it. So the trick here is to
actually get rid of this protein

here, PD1. There's another kind of
protein out there, too. They call these checkpoints,
that actually they

keep things in check and
prevent things from eating them. But you can modify these.

And so either by
themselves-- and these days there's also another
genetic trick

used where actually can promote
the attack of these cancer cells. And this one
definitely uses CRISPR.

And this one usually
uses gene addition, but can involve modification
using CRISPR as well.

So the point out of all
this is that we can now treat cancer using some of
these same technologies.

Again, very, very powerful. People are talking about trying
to use this to try and block

viral infections. So just like the original
idea with bacteria, imagine you have CRISPR
sequences embedded

in some of your cells. And this is being used
for HIV, by the way, where

you would actually-- well,
for this case, the idea is you would actually have
these CRISPR RNAs all set up

to attack, if you
will, SARS-CoV-2. Now this uses a
little bit of a trick.

SARS is an RNA virus. There's a new kind of CRISPR
out that actually attacks RNA.

And so the idea here is that
you would use this new system to block SARS. But people are actually talking
about modifying your cells.

You may know there's a
receptor on your cells for HIV. So when people
get HIV, the virus

spreads throughout their immune
cells because of this receptor. It's called the CCR5. So people are actually
talking about--

and there are trials
underway, as you might have seen,
to eliminate that so that if you get rid of
that, then HIV can't spread

and you actually get some good
immune cells to help protect yourself. So that's being explored
as a very interesting

possible therapy for at least
reducing HIV and coming up

with a set of very
good immune cells. So HIV folks can have
a good immune system.

It's not just humans people
are talking about doing this. There's wide potential
in agriculture.

We run a biotechnology
course in our program,

and you can read all about
all the different ways you can manipulate agriculture. There's a lot of very
clever-- and some of this

is already being used for
making weed resistance

and actually improving
the nutrients within food people are talking about.

And what's special
here-- and also, I should say, it turns
out, preserving fruits

and vegetables, a big deal. 30% to 40% of fruits
and vegetables spoil.
They never get into a stomach. A lot of them die in transplant.

There is spoil. And then a lot die
in your fridge. So really, if you can
make things resistant--

there are tricks for doing
this, for manipulating some of the
signaling things that actually lead to resistance.

And so people are
talking about trying to, again, do food preservation
to make better nutrients, so

antioxidants. In general, as you get older,
you have more oxidative stress.

So the goal is to have
more antioxidants. GABA is an interesting
molecule and provitamins,

things like that. And one important
point listed here is that what's different about
this from, say, adding genes

through viruses and things, that
actually modifies the plants.

And same with humans. If you do viral addition
to get things in,

that's considered a more
serious gene manipulation, whereas if you actually
do CRISPR Cas9,

you don't leave any
viral sequences behind if you use those nanoparticles. And so what you're
doing is you're

able to modify the
genome, and you're not adding any exogenous things,
like viruses and things like that.

People worry your immune
system is going to attack it. So they're generally
not considered GMOs

if you use this technology
because it's a lot cleaner. And so these are some
of the things that have

been manipulated in the past. And some of this,
I should say, is for actually getting resistance
to plant viruses that

attack and destroy these, too. So it's another area. Finally, there's all
kinds of clever other ways

to use CRISPR. I think one of the
most interesting ones right now-- it's
very, very topical.

Some of you may
have just seen this. But people obviously want
to control mosquitoes.

And mosquitoes,
I'm sure you know, they carry very nasty pathogens,
malaria, West Nile virus, Zika.

And malaria in
particular has been a rage for much of the planet
for a long time, especially

tropical areas, and it's
been hard to eliminate. And so people use nasty
pesticides, things like that.

And nobody really wants
to use those chemicals. They have other side effects
that aren't so great. And they're very nonspecific.

They don't just
wipe out mosquitoes. They wipe out tons of stuff. So one of the very,
very clever ways to use,

is actually the most common
way is using this one here, is actually you can
still sterilize males.

Mosquitoes tend to
mate once, females do. And so what you can do is
you can use CRISPR Cas9

to sterilize the males,
and then actually they'll mate with the females who
then won't mate again.

Because the males were
sterile, the females don't have mosquito
babies, so to speak.

They don't make larvae and such. And so the net result
is that you can actually

reduce population. So there are trials
running right now. In fact, I forgot how many. It's just a huge
number mosquitoes

they're releasing right now
in the Florida Keys that are manipulated this way. And even in California,
where we are,

actually now trials are about
to launch from both these two sites using very, very
large numbers of mosquitoes.

So they've run pilots
on this before. These are considered pilots
as well, larger pilot.

And so this likely will reduce
the mosquito population size,

and therefore hopefully
release these things without wiping out all insects. It will be very, very specific
for a very specific class

of mosquitoes. One particular kind of mosquito
is the major culprit in this.

And so this is this. And there's even some
other tricks you can use, something called gene
drive, to try and actually

drive it even further. So anyway these are
some of the clever ways in which you can use this.

But it does raise
questions some might be thinking about right now. All right, so we can go around
and modify people's DNA.

Well, should we do this? Is this a good thing to do? And nobody's going to argue
with modifying life-threatening

diseases. I think we all would agree
that that's a good thing. But what about other things?

And some people say,
well, if we can figure out genes for intelligence, we
can't right now very well.

We don't have strong
genes for this. And they're complicated. So it's not usually
single genes.

But should we go around
and modify all this? And so again, I
don't think anybody's

going to have a hard
time with nasty diseases, trying to fix them.

Also, if you fix
them somatically, meaning not in the germline,
but like I mentioned,

fixing people's blood,
that's perfectly fine. It's not going to
pass on to the kids.

You're going to hopefully
cure the person. That's all good and exciting. Again, totally
non-controversial.

But what about going
into the germline to start changing things
so future generations might

be affected? And what if some
of these things-- we don't know
100%, exactly, when

you start buggering
up people's genomes, are we causing issues
we don't know about?

And so people are very
cautious, justifiably so, about what you can
and can't do here.

Also, I should point
out the technology, it's gotten pretty good
lately, but people still

worry about what's called
off-target effects. You're trying to manipulate
a specific locus.

But with some low
frequency, you often get changes elsewhere
in people's DNA.

And what if, while you're
trying to fix one thing, you create a problem
somewhere Else And that has
happened, by the way,

in genetic engineering
before, where trying to fix
someone's immune system

has led to an
increase in cancer, for example, in
one kind of trial. And that required a lot of
reworking to figure that out.

So we want to make
sure we get it right, things are working well. But there was a case not long
ago where a person in China--

it wasn't illegal, what he did. He went in and modified
three embryos, human embryos,

actually. One was twin girls and another
was from another family.

And this is the AIDS receptor,
the CCR5, the HIV 1 receptor,

gene receptor. And so he went in and
modified this gene. The father had AIDS,
and his argument

was, well, this
will help protect the kids from getting AIDS. A lot of people felt
it wasn't necessary

because there are other ways
he could have these kids and they wouldn't necessarily--

they were in vitro fertilized. They got the embryo. So it's not clear 100%
you had to do this.

But he jumped up at a meeting
and presented his results

from these first
twins, and it really exploded into a big controversy.

Almost everyone blasted
him because at the time, the technology was still new. It wasn't clear how much there
were these off target effects.

It really created a big stink. But there was one very prominent
scientist who said, hey,

what he did is perfectly fine. He's trying to actually
help this family

and have girls that
won't get AIDS, which was the main argument
of this fellow here.

In the end, he self-created
a big controversy with most people weighing severely against
him because he did kind of do

it-- he wanted to make a
big splash, and he did.

And in the end,
though, he actually did wind up in jail because
the way he ran the study,

a lot of it was unethical. He didn't quite notify
the family quite right is my understanding, and he
wasn't completely honest.

There's always
review boards when you work with human subjects.

You have to get approval and
get everything tidied up nicely. And he was accused
of not doing that.

So he did wind up in
jail for three years. Just got released this year. So anyway, but the
point out of all of this

is that first of all,
this is the real deal. We will be editing people.

And certainly, again,
semantically, not in germline-- that's a no brainer--

but in germline,
there will be a time when we will be editing people. And so the question is,
what's the right approach?

How do we make sure it's safe? All these things. And so there'll be
committees set up and guidelines to be able to do
this in a responsible fashion.

I will say, though,
that as a research tool, CRISPR, again,
has just exploded. I talked about modifying DNA.

But it turns out there
are versions of this-- I alluded to this-- where
with this one, Cas13 you can actually
directly modify RNA.

Now that's kind of interesting
because if you modify RNA, you're not changing germlines.

And there are many
applications where this could be very, very favorable. You don't have to worry
about causing cancer

because it's temporary
when you go around and start modifying RNA.

There are other ways that this
is used for research purposes. You can re-engineer
these guide RNAs

to be able to bring
in inhibitory proteins or things that will
directly modify your DNA,

like DNA methylation change,
what's called the epigenome. There are other kinds of ways of
using this technology as well.

And so it's just exploded. It's turned into
an incredible tool

to be able to use in
many, many different ways for helping us
understand our genome, modify the genome
to look at effects.

Most things that will
involve medical purposes will probably sit around
modifying DNA and RNA.

But for research
purposes, there's many, many different
ways to use this.

Future directions. Well, everything I just said. It's still the early days. We're going to see a lot more
of this for cancer therapeutics,

gene therapy methods. We're in a world where
we have to figure out how to feed the planet.

And being able to
increase yield, get disease-resistant plants
and food is a big deal for us

as a human civilization. And so we really will
need to improve all that.

And so there will be
ways of doing all this. And I mentioned even--

well, it will impact climate. Climate is getting
more severe, and so having drought-resistant
plants and things

like that will be a
very, very big deal. So that's really what I want
to tell you about CRISPR.

I know it's kind of just
a light touch on all this. You can dig deeper
in this program.

The Genetics and Genomics
Certificate Program teach about genetics,
sequencing technologies, all kinds of fun stuff,
including biotechnology,

that I alluded to here. And don't forget our
new CRISPR course, which you can take as well.

SPEAKER 1: We're
fielding questions here, and we can start
with the first one. Let me begin with the first
question, Dr. Snyder, which

is how do we ensure CRISPR
Cas9 goes to and edits the exact spot in the DNA?

MICHAEL SNYDER: Yeah. It comes down to designing
these guide RNAs just right.

They really like to target
their target sequence. And initially, when the
technology was set up,

they would do that,
but they would also recognize related sequences
around the genome. It was quite imperfect.

But the systems
have improved a lot. They've evolved. A lot of these systems either
grabbed better high fidelity

proteins and improved
the technology a lot. So actually, the number
of off target effects

is very, very low. And so it's quite
minimal these days.

Is it low enough to
go ahead and start modifying people's germline? That will be open
for discussion.

It's a great question. SPEAKER 1: The next
question is, how do we ensure the virus isn't
detrimental to the cell,

and how do we make sure it
just acts as a transport? MICHAEL SNYDER:
Yeah, good question.

So there's a lot of work around
this kind of thing for using viruses for transferring.

And in general, people think
a certain kind of virus-- we have a gene therapy module
in there in our program called

AAV-- generally, some of
the latest versions are thought to be fairly safe.

But having said that, people,
I think, to get around that, are using these nanoparticles. Same things you use
for vaccinations.

So they have zero
viral sequences. They're more lipid particles
for actually doing the transfer.

And so that's becoming
the more preferred route for actually transferring
CRISPR sequences and protein.

SPEAKER 1: Great. Thank you. Next question coming
up here is could you talk about how CRISPR
regulations are evolving,

and are some countries more
